narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A greater knowledge of Spanish in terms of grammar, vocabulary, and culture (of Spanish-speaking countries)
We developed our conversation skills and did a bit of writing.
I did not learn a lot of new grammar skills, but I appreciated being given the space to refine the skills that I learned in SPAN 120 in this class.
I learned some basic Spanish skills and grammar

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a very tough course due to the amount of work each day.

I do not believe this course was organized at all for learning. I talked to many students who reported that their Spanish had declined over the semester. Mine did too. Too often, our in-class work was simply putting some words on a Jamboard and then saying them aloud when called on. The class gave us no reason to try to learn vocabulary or new grammatical structures. There wasn't a single vocabulary quiz, and we were allowed to use Word Reference on the two exams. In other words, the class was easy because there was so little to do. For grammar, we barely learned any new structures, and none of them required more than a cursory glance before taking the test. L2 Spanish was more challenging than this course, and L2 Spanish was better for it. For the life of me, I do not know why this class did not have actual grammar and vocabulary evaluations. Everything just felt like filler between substantive lessons that never came. Or, put differently, this felt like some kind of experimental teaching style that didn't work out at all. If the point of the class was to increase our spoken skills, it failed on that aim, too. The final assignment, for example, was to create a script for a scene in a book we read and then act it out. But we all just the script off our phones, so how does that do anything for our conversation skills? Also, why are we paying hundreds of dollars for a textbook we didn't use at all? And finally, why did we go from doing less than 20 minutes of work a night to suddenly reading thousands of words in Spanish every night when we read the book by Garcia Marquez? Why would we cram that into a single week when it was by far the most intense part of the semester?

Strengths: the course engages with a wide range of topics and students have plenty of opportunities to practice thinking about these topics in Spanish

Weaknesses: the work, though not necessarily challenging, can be quite tedious at times

I feel like there was a lot of busy work and I did not engage in the course/materials a lot. With the class being 5 days a week and filled with lots of busy work assignments, I prioritized completing the homework over really engaging. I feel like we could have done more work on any grammar/vocab.
She needs to grade faster and provide more feedback
Tedious at times but mostly a good class.

Strengths: great curriculum, interesting topics and readings, by and large good and useful assignments
Weaknesses: low incentives to work led to low class engagement. Very little feedback from professor. Course was in general unclear and disorganized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: L3 is a tough course, but overall, it was enjoyable when in classroom situations.

I imagine that students taking L3 Spanish are going to take it regardless of what I write here, because most of us were taking it for our language credit. So, take it if you are doing that, because you can't avoid it. But I'd say that you should avoid it if you can. It felt like a waste of time, energy, and tuition. The experience this semester suggests that--even more than L1 and L2 spanish--there should be an intensive version of L3 and L4 together for students who actually want to learn the language.
Yes, as a continuation of SPAN 120 as you will have the chance to use knowledge from SPAN 120 for readings, discussions, and written assignments in this class.

No, I feel like there is a better way to learn Spanish than 5 days a week in the early mornings. I sometimes felt like I didn't need to come to class (if it wasn't mandatory) and could have sat for the exams without going at all and still done fine. The busy work at this level was frustrating.
Only if you have to take it
